TextView.android:text: Consent Form For Enrolling Adult Participants in a Research Study
Protocol and Consent Title: Evaluation of a Balance and Cognitive Dual-Task in College Students; 07/08/19v3
The Dual Task Assessment Tool used in this research project is for investigational purposes only and has not been approved for the intended use by the FDA.
The purpose of this study is to evaluate a new assessment tool for concussion called Dual-Task which combines balance and cognitive (memory) testing using a virtual reality (VR) system.

Participants in this study must be within the ages of 18 and 29 years old. Subjects can be of either sex. The target population is college students. Subjects must be physically active (at least 30 minutes of exercise, 3 times of week). Subjects cannot have had a concussion or concussive-like symptoms in the past 6 months. Eligible subjects must be able to stand and walk with no complaints of dizziness or imbalance. Subjects are excluded if they have a history of any of the following: seizure disorder, claustrophobia (fear of tight spaces), peripheral neuropathy (weakness, numbness, and pain from nerve damage), lower extremity orthopedic problems that prevent standing or walking. Subjects are excluded if they have any drug or alcohol use within the previous 12 hours. Participants also cannot currently be under the care of a doctor for these or any related conditions that may cause an issue where individuals have trouble remembering, learning, concentrating, or making everyday decisions.

We expect to enroll 40 college-aged individuals in this study. If you decide to be in this study, your part will involve one visit. During the visit, which will take approximately 35 minutes, you will complete a brief medical history questionnaire and a pre-simulator sickness questionnaire (SSQ). This will be followed by a balance test (modified balance error scoring system, BESS) and a memory test (modified sports concussion assessment tool, SCAT) both with a VR headset. Then Dual-Task (balance and memory tests together) will be tested followed by a post-SSQ. After that, you will take a 10-minute break while wearing either control goggles or concussion (i.e. vision distortion) goggles and playing a cup stacking game. You will then take another Dual-Task and another post-SSQ. All instructions for the BESS, SCAT, and Dual-Task will be given in the VR headset. Each VR session (4 in total) will take 2 minutes, for a total of 8 minutes of VR time. Remember, you may stop at any time.

The following risks or discomforts may occur as a result of your participation in this study. Due to the VR environment, testing may cause physical or emotional discomfort to some participants with claustrophobia. Other potential risks include fatigue (extreme tiredness), eyestrain, and motion sickness. You can stop testing and remove the device at any time during the study. During balance testing, there is a risk of fall. We will follow safety procedures similar to a clinical assessment or physical therapy. If you lose balance during the assessment, we are guarding you to prevent a fall. If fatigue arises during the VR sessions, you may take as much rest as requested.

There are no direct benefits to you. The target population for eventual use of this test is young adults (high school and college aged people), both athletes and non-athletes. Your participation in this study may benefit people in the future.
You will be compensated $10 for your time and effort. This $10 will be presented in the form of a Starbucks gift card. Once you are enrolled in the study, you will be compensated.

Your participation in this study is gratefully acknowledged. It is possible that your information/data will be enormously valuable for other research purposes. By signing below, you consent for your de-identified information/data to be stored by the researchers and to be shared with other researchers in future studies. If you agree to allow such future sharing and use, your identity will be completely separated from your information/data, and none of this information be used for commercial profit. Future researchers will not have a way to identify you. Any future research must be approved by an ethics committee before being undertaken.
There will be no photographs, audio, or video recording taken of you during any point of the study.

The following procedures will be followed to keep your personal information confidential in this study. Your privacy will be protected to the extent required by law. To protect your privacy, your records will be kept under a code number rather than by name. Your records will be kept in locked files. Unless you give specific consent otherwise, only study staff will be allowed to look at them. If your data is wished to be used for future research, an ethics committee’s approval will be required before proceeding. Your name and any other fact that might point to you will not appear when results of this study are presented or published. The Georgia Institute of Technology IRB, the Office of Human Research Protections, and/or the Food and Drug Administration may look over study records during required reviews.
There are no costs to you, other than your time, for being in this study.
● Your participation in this study is voluntary. You do not have to be in this study if you don't want to be.
● You have the right to change your mind and leave the study at any time without giving any reason and without penalty.
● Any new information that may make you change your mind about being in this study will be given to you.
● You will be given a copy of this consent form to keep.
● You do not waive any of your legal rights by signing this consent form.
